p.text: I've been writing software since 1993, almost entirely using international standards. Just about every thing I do is built using C++ / STL (ISO 14882) and geared toward complete platform independence.
I try to make sure that everything I write may be easily ported to any mainstream operating system.

Content.p: I've worked on a wide variety of projects, and have seen a lot of different styles. Many projects depend on systems that are built using proprietary libraries, and some depend on operating systems that are designed to not follow standards. But, even in the worst case scenario, standards based code is easy to port. Building solid solutions is a matter of using solid design principles.

p.text: Most of the time, solutions to complex problems can be solved with generic methods. A web server is a good example. Servers are complicated, and must answer some difficult problems, but a server that can only suit the needs of one program is virtually worthless.
Software is a team effort. A software engineer may be highly skilled, and understand software design completely, but get nowhere without the support of many other talents.
In my opinion, the best approach is to have a good attitude, and find productive environments. Teams that work well together get things done.
